qas.question: What did The Sun state that had it taken sponsorship of?
What did the wording on the side of The Sun missile state?
Who did The Sun state that the missile would be used against?
How did troops react to the missile?
What was the name of The Sun journalist who reported on the missile?

context: On 1 May, The Sun claimed to have 'sponsored' <a0_0>a British missile<a0_0/>. Under the headline "Stick This Up Your Junta: A Sun missile for Galtieri’s gauchos", the newspaper published a photograph of a missile, (actually a Polaris missile stock shot from the Ministry of Defence) which had a large Sun logo printed on its side with the caption <a1_0>"Here It Comes, Senors..."<a1_0/> underneath. The paper explained that it was 'sponsoring' the missile by contributing to the eventual victory party on HMS Invincible when the war ended. In copy written by Wendy Henry, the paper said that the missile would shortly be used against <a2_0>Argentinian forces<a2_0/>. Despite this, <a3_0>it was not well received<a3_0/> by the troops and copies of The Sun were soon burnt. <a4_0>Tony Snow<a4_0/>, The Sun journalist on HMS Invincible who had 'signed' the missile, reported a few days later that it had hit an Argentinian target.
